name: Botsonic by Codex Solutions International
title: Botsonic by Codex Solutions International
description: How to integrate Botsonic with Make.com

children.text: Botsonic is an AI-powered chatbot builder that enables businesses to create custom chatbots for websites and customer support. Integrating with Make.com allows automated workflows, enhancing customer engagement and streamlining support processes across multiple platforms.
This is AI-generated content based on official Botsonic documentation. The content may still contain errors—please verify important information. If you have questions, contact
How to get support on Botsonic

Botsonic is a community-developed application and is subjected to the developer's terms and conditions, which may include applicable fees. Make does not maintain or support this integration. For assistance, please https://f.make.com/r/reachout?app_name=Botsonic&app_slug=botsonic-community&app_unique_id=botsonic-g6853t.
To use the Botsonic app in Make,
you must have an active account and an API token,
To install this app, you need Admin, Owner, or App Developer permissions.
the on-screen instructions to complete the setup.
To get started, you must first create a connection between Botsonic and
, allowing the two services to communicate.
You can connect using the following method: API Key,Secret Key.
You need to generate a secret key to authenticate.
Login to your platform using your credentials.
Click API from the left hand side menu.
Enter a name for the secret key, then click Create Secret Key to generate a new secret key.
Copy and save the secret key somewhere safe. When you exit the pop-up box, you will no longer be able to view it again, you will need to generate a new one.
You need to generate your secret key.
Login to your platform using your credentials.
Click API from the left hand side menu.
Enter a name for the secret key.
Click Create Secret Key to generate a new secret key.
Copy and save the secret key somewhere safe. When you exit the pop-up box, you will no longer be able to view it again, you will need to generate a new one.
Some community developers require an additional specific
from the community developer's dashboard, generally found under
, add the Botsonic module to your
If you add a module with an instant tag, click
field, enter a name for the connection.
you copied from your Botsonic or follow the on-screen instructions to create the connection. You must also enter any required third-party API keys obtained earlier.
For detailed information on connecting an application, see
After connecting to the Botsonic app, you can choose from a list of available modules to build your
Creates a brand new bot for your account, allowing you to automate tasks or interact with users according to your settings.
Creates a bot FAQ, allowing you to set up a list of frequently asked questions and answers for your bot to help users find information quickly.
Remove a specific bot from your account by providing its unique ID.
Remove a specific bot FAQ from your system by providing its unique ID. This module allows you to delete a particular FAQ entry associated with your bot.
This module allows you to generate results instantly by sending a request and receiving the response right away. It’s perfect for tasks where you need immediate output from the generation endpoint.
Retrieve detailed information about a particular bot by specifying its unique ID. This module allows you to access all the key details related to that specific bot.
Retrieve a complete, paginated list of all bots, allowing you to browse through them page by page.

Retrieve a complete list of frequently asked questions (FAQs) associated with a specific bot. This module allows you to access all the FAQs that have been set up for that bot, making it easy to view or manage the information users might need.

Perform a custom API request to the connected service, allowing you to access specific endpoints or actions that may not be available through the standard modules. This gives you flexibility to retrieve or send exactly the data you need.
You can look for more templates in
, where you'll find thousands of pre-created

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
